captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

Hot hatches and UK roads
are like roast beef and
horseradish sauce--

so perfect in each other's
company, you wonder if they

weren't designed purely
for each other.

Now Ford is a master of turning
a shopping trolley

into something genuinely
fast and exciting.

So the new Focus ST, now with
just four cylinders, is a good

reason to see what's happening
on Planet Hatchback.

Up against the Ford are the
exceptional Renaultsport

Megane and the very
potent Astra VXR.
Winner takes all.

Try not to drive them
like a nutter.

But that's actually
not possible in
one of these, right?
[CAR ENGINE]

The Astra VXR is one of
the least subtle cars
on sale in the UK.

Normally, Vauxhall's efforts
in the VXR department are

uncouth, and I say, not
very good on the road.

But this little GTC-based car
is, I think, quite funky.
[CAR ENGINE]
It's just quite unruly.
OK.

How have we got this performance
in this package?

We've got a front-wheel drive
car on the other two, and

we've got a shedload of
power and torque,
but it's less subtle.

Delivery is more difficult
in this car.
There's more lag.

So you have to kind of
anticipate what's going on.

Now some people might find
that a pain in the ass.

I could at times, but actually
it makes for
quite an amusing device.

You can sort of left foot brake
it and then just wind

the throttle and then wait
for it to come in.

On a smooth A-road, it feels
really quite good.

On a bumpy B-road, it's
a bit oversprung.
It's a bit underdamped.

And that's before you hit the
VXR button, which makes things

more aggressive in terms of
throttle and even more

aggressive in terms
of spring rate.

Or they use the damper,
don't they?

Then it becomes very
unruly indeed.
[CAR ENGINE]

There's much to love and
celebrate about this car,

though, because it's an honest
in-your-face hot hatch.

If you like your hair combed
in 19 different directions

with a product, and the priority
when buying jeans is

whether you can show the top two
inches of your ass crevice

to the world, then you're going
to love the way this
thing looks.
It's full-on.

The basic shape is
great as well.

These seats are excellent,
I have to say.

It's a theme with
all three cars.

They've really tried
with the cabin.
They're fantastic.
They're massive, comfortable.

They just look sporty,
don't they?
The rest of the cabin, hmm.
Yes.

It's going to take me a long,
long time to get used to what
these buttons do.

They're so small, you spend
half your time looking at
what's going on.
It's just in your face.
It's very honest about that.

So if you want it, the VXR
kind of offers it.

Anyway, this may have a
similarly stiff chassis to the

VXR, but after that, the
similarities kind of end.

Renaultsport are very good
at making hot hatchbacks.

And this thing is
no exception.

The first time you get in this
Megane, you could be mistaken

for thinking after the other
two, well, the cabin's
completely bare.

It feels like it should be worth
about half the money.

And even when you drive it
slowly, you might think,
what's all the fuss about?

But the moment you get going in
it, you realize that this

has had some proper attention
lavished on it.
It is superb.

Dif means it's got more traction
in the wet here.

And the faster you drive it, the
harder you drive it, the
more it brings back to you.

The gear shift has
a shorter throw.
The steering is fast.
The whole car comes alive.

And I've said this before, but
that RS moniker kind of fits

the car the way it does
those Porsche models.

They just feel very,
very special.

It's quite harsh, but
interestingly, the faster you

go, the more controlled
it feels.

The complete opposite of the
VXR, which, if you really

push, starts to lose it a
bit and get a bit baggy.
I do love these things.
The motor--

actually, the motor is starting
to feel a little bit

tired now, because the Ford,
as you'll find, that has a
great engine.

And that VXR, it's got
more punch than this.

And this, actually, is
still quite laggy.

I just love the way that on a
damp day, you can cover ground
so quickly in these things.

Part of the reason why the car
gives you so much confidence

in these damp conditions out
here is the steering.

At very low speed,
it seems to have
absolutely no feel at all.

But when you get going, it's
just right, I think.
It's just right.
Special car, this.
Special car.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now in some respects, it's a bit
unfair taking a Focus ST

and putting it against the
Megane Renaultsport and also a

VXR, because that's an RS's
job, really, isn't it?

So we're perhaps a bit too far
down the Ford food chain.

But this thing acquits itself
very, very well,
even in this company.
[CAR ENGINE]

There is much to appreciate
in this car.

I will start with the engine,
which has much more response
than the other two.
It doesn't have much lag.

There's a little bit, but it
just feels very elastic,

giving you whatever you want
when you demand it.

So that means that on the road,
it feels just as quick
as the other two.

Perhaps in terms of immediate
response, it feels quicker.
The steering--

to start with, it feels
just too quick.

But I quite like the fact that
you work without turning your

arms over the wheel
and grabbing
extra armfuls of lock.
The chassis.

Softer, more subtle, and it
works with a UK road just
better than the other two.

As an everyday car, this
is a nicer place to be.
The seats--
exceptional.
With Recaro logos everywhere.

I'm not too old to
enjoy those.
Yes, it's a great road car.

I sort of miss the fact that
you can't get a three-door,

and it has to be a five-door,
but you get used
to that quite quickly.

It's a funky looking
car, isn't it?
The cabin--

now, some people that have
driven this car this week

think it's just a bit too
complicated and chavved up.

Me, well, some people like lots
of complication and cool
stuff going on.
It is a bit too much.

This Sony hi-fi can't
always work out.

But the rest of it, it just
feels like Ford's tried to

give you a lot of stuff
for your money.

And in the most part,
it works.
[CAR ENGINE]

Can a hot hatch really
have electric power
steering and work?

OK, it is kind of lacking any
kind of feel, and what Ford

has done is given it a load of
resistance just off center.

So the car gives you initial
resistance just off center
that you feel as weight.

The problem is, it's quite
aggressive self-centering back
the other way.

So if I let go of the wheel,
the car straightens
immediately.
That is not very realistic.

But you quickly build a rhythm
with the car where you just

sort of steer it quite lightly,
and you don't need to

use too much lock to get around
quite tight bends.

It's a different
way of driving.

It doesn't feel like a young,
small, angry, hot hatchback.

It feels quite mature
and grown up.

It feels like a really nice car
to live with year round.
[CAR ENGINE]

So the Ford noses ahead on the
road, but what happens when

you send them around a tight,
rather wet, little circuit?
[CAR ENGINE]
Okay.
Llandow Circuit.
Wicked little place.
[CAR ENGINE]
In the Focus.

I've got the traction
on at the moment.

It's so slippery,
it's definitely
worth keeping it on.
[CAR ENGINE]

The fact that it's a bit
softer than the others
probably helps it quite a lot.
[CAR ENGINE]

Do like the chassis bounce
in this car.

It's just got a slightly mobile
rear end on it, which

means that if you peered away
from the throttle a bit, it

would just help the
car into the turn.
It's not too lairy.
It's not dangerous.

It's just what I'd
call mobile.
Very tight little places.

It's almost like a
go-kart track.
[CAR ENGINE]

In this Ford, in these
conditions I have to say, very
impressive indeed.
System's working really well.
I've got some turn in.

I haven't got too
much understeer.

Compared to the Audi RS3 the
other week, I had monstrous
understeer.
I haven't with this.
[CAR ENGINE]

Real advantage of this sort of
weather, being front wheel

drive, you just lean
on the throttle.
[CAR ENGINE]

In these conditions, I
really like this car.

In fact, I just like
it full stop.
It's nice.
It's supple.
Its engine, listen to it.
250 horsepower.
Makes a great noise.

There's clearly some sort of
intake resonator thing going

on, but it's not
too artificial,
and it's just cool.
It is just cool.

I love hatchbacks in this
sort of weather.

Systems have come a long
way, haven't they?

I'm just leaning on
this thing now.

Where the rain's coming in hard,
you just stay wide open.
[CAR ENGINE]
Cracking little car.

Balance, good brakes, they're
not getting too much fade,

good wet weather grip,
good traction.

Just get the feeling this has
been developed by people that
like driving.
You know what?
That's a good thing.
[CAR ENGINE]

The Megane Renaultsport
in its preferred
element, the circuit.

Let's drop that steering
wheel down a bit.
What's it like here, then?
Feels pokey.

Immediately, I like the
size of the car.
I like the way that it feels.
I like the way that it steers.

Again, like the others, they've
got balance, traction.
There's a locker in this.
You can feel it.
Yes.
[CAR ENGINE]
We'll leave it in second.
Bounce over a couple of curbs.

Again, the rear axle's quite
mobile, wants to get us--
wants to help us round.
[CAR ENGINE]
Oh yes.
Oh yes.

Feels more agile than
the others.
Brakes are good.
All the controls are good.

Like the steering column's come
back to me a little bit.
OK.

We're being held back a bit by
the traction control there, so
it's going off.

Let's try a lap without
the traction on, OK?

In the others I left it on
because it wasn't getting in

the way, but in this, I
think it is, slightly.
[CAR ENGINE]

Front-wheel drive cars are just
so flipping competent
these days.
That feels good.

That just feels bloody
marvelous.
[CAR ENGINE]

What a wicked bit
of kit this is.
It just pendulums a bit.
Cracking thing.
Cracking, cracking thing.

I'm so glad Renault still makes
cars like this, because

it's got some difficulties in
other areas, but it's fabby.
Absolutely fabby.
[CAR ENGINE]

This is a slightly unfair test
for the Astra, because it's

got extra power over the others,
but this wet whether

is going to negate
some of that.

Even so, let's see
how it gets on.

We're on the back, straight,
third gear, fourth gear, over
100 miles an hour.
Braking hard.
Get third.
Pedal's not ideal.
Quick through the chicane.

Fast direction change, and
the car takes it well.

I have to say, the car
takes it well.
Now this back straight.

Turn it in early, open the taps
up, dif and electronics

working really quite well
in these conditions.

This is so much better than the
last generation of these
cars that I drove.

I braked a bit early there, so
this time we can carry a bit
more speed, I think.

We'll try one more quick
one through there.
Car's flat, steering's quick.

It doesn't have the suppleness
of the Ford, and it doesn't

have the immediacy of the Ford's
throttle response.

But this really is so much
better than I expected.

These VXR products can be quite
disappointing, and I

think this is quite a
nice car, actually.
Certainly fast.

I'm not finding the pedal
position very
easy, have to say.

But on a track like this in
these conditions, that VXR
mode is best left well alone.

Hatchbacks are just
cool, aren't they?

Through these curby sections,
good direction changes.

You can just get that dif
hooked up, and it goes.
This quicker right hand.

Again, there's mobility
to the rear axle.

Makes it fun, makes
it adjustable.
Bit of oversteer there.
I like this.
Well done, Vauxhall.
Well bloody done.
Woo hoo!
Oh, yeah.

This is a good feeling, to
drive a Vauxhall product
that's this much fun.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now, I make no apologies for
this being a deliberately and

unashamedly UK-based test,
because these cars are perfect

for our roads and our
weather conditions.

They are three very, very
good cars, actually.

So a general harumph
all around.

This is a very, very
talented class.

Sadly, a car has to
come last, though.
And that is the Vauxhall.

Strangely, it is the biggest
surprise of the test for me,

because I expected it
to be dreadful.

But just by a few degrees in
every department, it is the
weakest car here.

And I think at 27,000 pounds,
it's quite expensive for what

it offers, although it
is very, very fast.

It's miles better than
the last VXR I drove.
So well done, Vauxhall.

Picking a winner is
more difficult.

I'm going to give
you two winners.

If you want to do some track
date, and you want the

ultimate sharp front-wheel drive
experience, you have to
go for the Megane.
It's just exceptional.

But if I was going to live with
a hot hatch for the next

year, it would have to be a
Focus ST. It's lovely on the

road and surprisingly capable
on the track, as well.
One last note, though.

This Focus ST is getting
quite expensive.

It's 28,000 pounds as tested
with a few extras.

So the M135i is shaking things
up a bit here, isn't it?

That car, at just under
30,000 pounds, puts
immense pressure on these.

But there's something about
capable, well-packaged

front-wheel drive performance
that I'll always love.
Yeah.
Good cars.

title: Ford Focus ST Hot Hatchback Showdown - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: ASTARA VXR  <3﻿
comments.author: Soni Vlore

comments.text:
wish I could get the Megane in the States. I am excited for the Focus RS 
though.  ﻿
comments.author: NostalgicColors

comments.text:
In terms of an "every day" car they should have the GTI in there. Don't 
care if it's not as fast, 1 remap and the power issue is sorted. ﻿
comments.author: Greig Mackenzie

comments.text:
I own a performance blue Focus ST and love it. It's a great daily driver 
with tons on aftermarket support. Unfortunatly we don't get the other two 
here is the US so options for hot hatches are limited. It would be fun to 
try the Renaultsport Megane and VRX. At least we can sort of try them on 
Forza for Xbox. Great video comparison. ﻿
comments.author: STredline

comments.text:
Hi verdict is not even based on the facts he highlighted of the cars during 
the test.  I mean the VXR came last because he expected it to be dreadful 
compared to the previous model! Huh! He has proven it to be better around 
the track coming No.1 without the VXR mode on.  Then he says Megan is the 
one to take to the track.  VXR is better looking of the 3 but as everyday 
drive Ford takes the lead. So this test just highlighted that VXR and Megan 
are neck to neck.  True hot hatches ready for the track and lack a bit when 
comes to everyday drive but good enough.  Ford is your everyday drive kinda 
hot hatch but not hot enough for the track.  So it tries to give you the 
best of both world but it doesn't.  It doesn't even stand out but reminds 
one that word ugly exists.﻿
comments.author: Liscious Mokoka

comments.text:
Exactly i thought the same, almost fell off my chair when he announced the 
VXR last. The complete tool
comments.author: steve legends

comments.text:
chris harris hates on the vxr on top gear not that jeremy clarkson is a 
proper road tester these days but he sang its praises round the track where 
didnt rate the focus all that much﻿
comments.author: bensmithkent22

comments.text:
Chris ... Did you put the RS on it's "extreme" sports mode setting because 
there is no way that the opel would beat it on the track if you did. The RS 
has 5 sports mode settings and I think you went round on the progressive 
setting .﻿
comments.author: arnie365

comments.text:
great car test!! no shit music over the engine noise and good explanations. 
Thanks!﻿
comments.author: billy bill

comments.text:
Chris, you are the among the best in this bussiness but your end results in 
this test come out a little weird...don't they?
I've been in all three of these cars and i can tell you this:
-Astra is the heaviest of them all...because it comes fully loaded...20" 
rims with 245 tyres,giant brakes,a locking diff by Drexler,three selections 
of performance regarding suspension/st. wheel/power delivery, all the 
electronics you could possibly want, the best seats in it's class (and 
above!),the best interior quality and the best looking... by very far.
-The Focus has been improved but it's interior is clearly TWO steps 
behind...just visit any auto show and compare!
It has four doors only and looks tall- not a proper "hot" hatchback then in 
my book, and looks plain and simple ugly.
-Untill now the RS was famed as a the ultimate track car.
A car with certain "problems" in everyday life (i've owned Meganes in the 
past) that one can pretend to accept in order to have the best in 
track...although i don't know how many actually use it in track...
Interior quality is on par (!) with the Focus and the plastic "bolt on" 
exterior parts make it look the most chav of the three.
But here comes the surprise:If i read the stopwatch well Astra was the best 
in track?
And this was done in the wet where the extra power and torque of a FWD car 
may come in as an handicap-your words?
-Last comes the price bomb:Astra at 27K is too expensive for what it 
offers...umm, but hey the Focus at 28K is getting expensive too... and 
watch this: the Megane comes at 26K base price (not even mentioned) that 
doesn't include the goodies pack (suspension tuning and locking diff) that 
costs 1350 quid more, making it 27.350 pounds...
The point about the BMW 135i is truly valid but this is a 3.0 liter car 
with all the problems this brings (tax-running costs).

I don't own a VXR but i do think there is a gigantic elefant in the room, 
and noone (you included) is willing to accept it's presence.
And the elefant is not the fact that the VXR comes last when it should 
probably come first, but the fact of the extreme prejudice in the 
auto-press against a manufacturer that has every right to get praised when 
he makes a good car.
It's the same story with Corsa Nurburg (i don't own that either!).
It beats the hell out of it's rivals but praise (a true, wholehearted one) 
hasn't been heard so far.
Just my 2c and i hope a little food for thought...﻿
comments.author: warpspeeed

comments.text: +warpspeeed wow you speek the absolute truth mate :-)
comments.author: Tom Forrest

comments.text:
I agree the Ford Focus ST is the best all rounder, but the Vauxhall Astra 
VXR is way better than Renault.﻿
comments.author: JamesYoow

comments.text: i wish America got these cars ﻿
comments.author: tobz d

comments.text:
I just picked up the Ford ST was this a risk for me in the USA?  Yes, Fords 
are not known for their reliability; seems my UK friends never mention this 
much on the reviews.  I thought I would give her a try; WOW it drive so 
well, very refined yet when you get on it and its turn in is fantastic. 
 The car really turns or should I say feels like it turns on it axis very 
neutral unlike my last hatch the Abarth Im finding it hard to find what 
needs to be ungraded.  The Abarth straight from the factory though easy to 
fix had many things I disliked but I loved the looks it got and the wow 
factor once upgraded how fast it seemed.  The ford is much faster but feels 
much less zippy than the Abarth.  I know why am Im comparing these 2 cars 
well my Abarth cost me 28K the Focus ST3 26K much better value the fit n 
finish much better the recardo seat are the real deal unlike the Abarths 
unfinished leather seat.  On a tight road I would give it to the upgraded 
Abarth but for everything else the ST has it in every other situation.  I 
so far could recommend the ST to anyone the Abarth well if you want a fun 
project car the Abrath very easy to mod.  I will be doing a video sub for 
updates﻿
comments.author: Doggorunning

comments.text:
Why are these hot hatches so expensive now?  Looking at the ST, it's 
$53,000 New Zealand dollars here, plus on road costs - my car, a Ford G6E 
Turbo costs $64,000, it's full sized, much better equipped, and much 
faster.  It must cost a LOT more to produce.  I think the manufacturers are 
milking the popularity of small cars to boost profits.﻿
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
+Firdaus Izam Absolutely, I've not driven the ST model, but I've driven a 
couple of lower end models and they are without a doubt fantastic little 
cars, I'd recommend one to anyone.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
+Matthew Sharpe Yeah, perhaps. We're going to have 6% gst tax starting in 
April. So the price would be going up for sure. Never mind that, this is a 
great car to buy. ☺
comments.author: Firdaus Izam

comments.text:
+Firdaus Izam can't even blame tax here, we have a 15 percent gst tax on 
everything and other than that not much in the way of import duty, plus 
company tax is pretty reasonable, I guess being in the middle of nowhere 
must make shipping expensive, but still, I'm betting margins are pretty 
fat.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
Talk about that, the ST in my country is at RM200,000 equivalent to 
$55,000. That damn tax!
comments.author: Firdaus Izam

comments.text: A brand new ST in America is about $24,000
comments.author: Michael Matta

comments.text:
+Tmans19 beats me! Like I said maybe they are milking the popularity of the 
small car segment? Just speculation of course.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
General Motors doesn't have the sack to bring the Vauxhall Astra(Opel) to 
the U.S. and the Nissan partnership with Renault (if it still exists) 
hasn't brought one of those here either, so the only game in the U.S. 
really is between the Ford Focus ST & VW Golf GTI.﻿
comments.author: Ray Adams

comments.text:
Still beats the Cruze we get from GM here. At least we could have a chance 
at keeping the competition in sight.
comments.author: Ray Adams

comments.text: Vauxhalls are for boguns anyway.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: I really wish the other two would be available here in the states﻿
comments.author: Shankidy Shank

comments.text: The editing's a bit off. Wipers on inside, wipers off outside...﻿
comments.author: ihadaralf

comments.text:
Wuuuuuuuuuuut!!? here in Mexico an ST fully loaded costs around 30k 
dollars, an M135 costs around 54k.. a BIG difference.﻿
comments.author: Pablo Rebolledo Toussaint

comments.text: Best tester ever, no loud music, just the sound of the engine, excellent !﻿
comments.author: Ccleanerable

comments.text:
I wish he would have tested the Focus & VXR with assists off like he did 
with the Megane.  I'm not saying it would have changed the results much but 
let's keep the comparison on even ground.﻿
comments.author: ZepG

comments.text:
Right so the VXR is quickest around the track, but yet he says the Megane 
is better on track.... right okay then....
Not the only Video where the VXR is quicker than the Megane around the 
track, anyone seen the one on Anglesey Circuit, VXR loads quicker than the 
Megane and the ST is just a piece of shit the brakes actually set on fire! 
Its not a track car!﻿
comments.author: goldie87skii

comments.text:
The Focus ST is not only a heck of a hot hatch, it's a really nice car to 
sit in and drive.  The fact that it hangs with the other 2 in this test is 
impressive.  I can't wait to see what the Focus RS can do.﻿

comments.text: no golf r again﻿

comments.text: I'd love to see this guy test the New Challenger and Mustang.﻿

comments.text:
Another great review from Chris. Hopefully going to get myself the focus st 
in a while, can't justify the money for the astra vxr and already have the

ford is not £28,000 maybe the estate one but Chris harris get that

yea i did cars do not get cheaper they usually get more expensive due to

comments.text:

comments.author: Ben Garlick

comments.text:
Astra Is Way to big it looks as wide as a Range rover and if your a petrol 
or gear head if your from the states and you like to slide this car or just 
do handbrake turns you cant it has a electronic parking brake :I Focus St 
any day. ﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Tom Forrest

comments.text: Compare the Vauxhall with the Opel :P﻿
comments.author: unknownguy1123

comments.text: same shit
comments.author: Jakub P

comments.text: I wouldn't trade my ST for either of those cars.... ST FTW!!﻿
comments.author: colbywan

comments.text: st interior is to boy racerish. gti is a nicer car by far﻿
comments.author: al bundy

comments.text: GTI is for wankers ;)
comments.author: TheRichrsturbo

comments.text:
I don't know what he's whining about the Astra and why does it come last?
Somebody here obviously doesn't like Vauxhall nor Opel...
So he said the throttle-response is a bit meh,
-but its still the fastest car here,
-it'll kick the Focus anyday, anywhere,
-its better equiped than the Megane R.S. and more sophistcated
-and its probably also the best looking (only without that "in your face" 
double-rear-spoiler)
The Astra is sort of the best of both worlds (nearly as grown up as the 
Ford and still keeping up with the Renault without a problem).﻿
comments.author: alfisti93

comments.text:
Performance on paper? He did a performance lap...where the astra comes 
first. So what is this review good for?
Don't worry I already have. :)
comments.author: alfisti93

comments.text:
its a simple review. who care. nobody buy a hatch for perf on paper or 
because its 3 in some classement. or idiots maybe. chose the car u like 
like i said before.
comments.author: thom si

comments.text:
First of all, i'd like to point out I called nobody a "twat". Whatever...
I was wondering about the objectivness of this comparison.
So tell me: which car is the fastest?
Which car is the most advanced?
Which one has the most extras available (as standard also)?
So its got nothing to do with "opinions" but a bit more with objective 
reviews...
All he mentioned that was bad about the Astra  was the "feeled" throttle 
response, so this is why it comes last? THATS ridicolous!
So do YOU know what car I own or were driving lately? I guess not.
comments.author: alfisti93

comments.text:
thats your opinion. ur saying he s a twat cause he didnt like but ur acting 
the same here defending a car witch u dont have. thats ridiculous dont you 
agree ? accept a car with the quality and default and take the car u like. 
some want the meg some the focus some the astra, thats the life.
comments.author: thom si

comments.text: Vxr all day look at it﻿
comments.author: gamertanafc

comments.text:
ST all the way. From these three cars I would take Focus ST any day, every 
day. No contest for me.

Fords always had this chasis balance that is unparaleled in the cars of 
that price range. You can really feel the car and what's it doing. I just 
haven't found that in other cars that go by that price.﻿
comments.author: Atrax1207

comments.text:
I have the new shape Ford Focus (Black) but it isnt the ST Model its a 1.6 
TDCI Diesel with 115 BHP, That also has the Steering Resistance where it 
aggressively corrects itself back to centre.. The Cockpit looks pretty much 
the same too, The only differances i can see are obviously the ST Tuned 
Engine, Body Kits, Wheels, Racing Seats & big central Exhaust System.. Ford 
Focus's are indeed great Cars tho...﻿
comments.author: jwatson9635

comments.text: don't forget the turbo it has 250 hp
comments.author: fordrulesf150

comments.text:
Great review. In the US, we unfortunately don't get the Renault or the 
Vauxhall but Ford of Europe now sent over the Ford Focus ST - and I bought 
one! That car is so much fun to drive, and the sound of the motor is so 
perfect, it's fantastic. I also test drove the new GTI and as nice/pleasant 
a car as it is, it's also a bit dull. Sorry VW, Ford got my money this 
time.﻿
comments.author: genericdenizen1

comments.text:
astra vxr all day, drove the focus st and wasn't impressed, not sure if i 
agree with chris on the throttle response, i felt the vxr had way better 
response and just ploughed ahead.﻿
comments.author: Tom Wainwright

comments.text:
I love how Chris Harris is so enthusiastic and seems to genuinely enjoy 
what he does, and he can actually drive properly!

Great review of some great hot hatches, they all look great but personally 
I'd take the Focus home with me.﻿

comments.text:
+scanthemelon Agreed. Front looks purposeful but the melting rear lights 
are very Korean. Shame, because I tried one on Scottish B roads last 
weekend and it's absolutely superb for the price. I enjoyed it far more 
than the clinical Golf R or hideously over-priced and inert A45 AMG. A 
proper analogue old school hatch.

comments.text:
Nontheless - no GTI wagons from any other manufacturer. For people who have 
familys or for people like me, who don't really like the normal hatchback 
body style, it's a bit sad.
comments.author: Roger Skagerström

comments.text:
The Megané RS and Astra OPC are two-door only. If you go smaller - so is 
the Fiesta ST. The Mazda 3 MPS (MS3) is four door, and the Golf GTI is 
available with four doors. That's the only ones we got in Sweden at least. 
The Mazda is proably beeing discontinued soon, as the new one is coming, so 
didn't count with that one. Forgot about the Golf though.
comments.author: Roger Skagerström

comments.text: What? No they're not! There isn't an exclusively 2 door GTI on the market!
comments.author: djorganix100

comments.text:
Important point is that the Focus is the only one available as a 4-door, 
and even wagon. I hate that almost all "GTI" cars are two-door only.
comments.author: Roger Skagerström

comments.text: Can't wait to see Chris test the 2015 Civic Type R!
comments.author: SlickRickOne

comments.text:
This I predict will lead to other parts of the car suffering, including 
putting the best possible 4WD system in. I don't know it might just be me 
but I remember the first ST had handling issues that were promptly 
corrected in later versions that along with other examples lead me to 
believe Ford focuses on power first and just engineers around the problems 
that come up later.
comments.author: Michael Swain

comments.text:
This would be an awesome idea as the festiva and focus both have bodywork 
and design that lends itself to making an excellent rally cars so they 
should do it. I am pessimistic though Ford are driving the multi-hothatch 
line and with the new Golf - R going below 5 seconds for 0-60 I think the 
first task the car engineers will be given is 'make the car faster' which 
can only mean more horses via an engine or a turbo.
comments.author: Michael Swain

comments.text:
Honestly if I was looking at near 'supercar performance on a budget' I 
don't know of a better stock car than picking up an evo X. I like the 
impreza but it just does not stack up to the evo in corners or handling. 
But in the hot hatch department check out the forthcoming Golf R which is 
set to send the standard 0-60 time competition to the 5 second and below 
mark. Which means 2 things great second hand car market and all engineers 
scrambling to get their new cars below 5 seconds.
comments.author: Michael Swain
